thread.title: Adherium IPO to raise $35 million to invest more in smart technology
thread.title_full: Adherium IPO to raise $35 million to invest more in smart technology

author: Vanessa Desloires
title: Adherium IPO to raise $35 million to invest more in smart technology
text:
Medical devices company Adherium is seeking to raise $35 million in its ASX float.
A medical devices company that is set to list on the ASX, hopes to lure big pharma contracts to sell its technology that could improve the health of respiratory disease sufferers.
Adherium is seeking to raise a maximum of $35 million through an initial public offering for a market capitalisation of $70 million.
Adherium Group chief executive officer Garth Sutherland said its product, Smartinhaler, a device which attaches to already available respiratory medication such as Ventolin, could put a significant dent into the estimated $US300 billion ($408 billion) spent globally on medical expenses related to the misuse of medication.
"Globally there is sub-optimal adherence to preventative medication, that is a big problem," he said.
Mr Sutherland, a lifelong asthma sufferer, said most medical professionals relied on the word of their patients as to their usage, which was unreliable and compromised their treatment.
"As a patient I had a need for something that could manage my asthma and that could automate that process," he said.
The device reminds patients to take their medication through an alarm and collects data on their usage which it sends to a smartphone app and to the cloud.
Institutional investors had already committed $28.85 million, and the company has signed on UK pharmaceutical giant AstraZeneca as a cornerstone investor for $3 million.
It also signed a 10-year supply and development agreement with AstraZeneca, which produces medications including Symbicort.
Mr Sutherland said the company's business-to-business model meant the pharmaceutical companies could package and distribute its product on a global scale.
Clinical trials in 29 countries had shown adherence to prescription medication jumped by 59 per cent in adults and 180 per cent in children.
The IPO is being managed by Bell Potter Securities, and corporate finance director Anton Whitehead said the company was compelling because it had 13 years already under its belt, and had an "enormous" market to sell to.
The respiratory medication industry is worth more than $US36 billion globally.
"It is very difficult to find listed companies let alone IPOs that have relationships with a large pharmaceutical company," he said.
Adherium has not provided profit forecasts and Mr Sutherland said it planned to invest funds raised in the IPO principally towards innovation, to keep in step with the rapid evolution of smart technology.
Seventy million shares have been issued at 50Â¢ each and the offer closes on August 14. The company will list on the ASX on August 26.
